title: Seven appeals ruling to pay a House Rules 'villain' compensation
text:
Channel Seven has lodged an appeal after the Workers Compensation Commission (WCC) ordered the network to pay a former House Rules contestant's medical bills.

Nicole Prince, who featured on season five in 2017 with her friend Fiona Taylor, won a case for medical expenses after she suffered 'psychological injury' and was left suicidal and unable to find work due to being portrayed as a bully on the show.

According to TV Tonight, an appeal against the decision has been lodged and will be determined early 2020.

Appealing: Seven has lodged an appeal after the Workers Compensation Commission ordered the network to pay former House Rules contestant Nicole Prince's (left) medical bills

Nicole had taken legal action through the WCC, which published its findings in a 27-page report earlier this week.

In her statement, which was first reported by TV Blackbox, she said she felt 'harassed and bullied' during filming.

'During every camera interview, both myself and Fiona complained on film that we were being subjected to isolation, bullying and harassment by the other teams,' she wrote.

'On one occasion I witnessed Fiona be physically assaulted. When I complained to Channel Seven, I was then threatened that Fiona and I would be portrayed negatively.'

Hardship: Nicole, who featured on season five of House Rules in 2017, won a case for medical expenses after she suffered 'psychological injury' on the renovation show

Decision: Nicole took legal action through the Workers Compensation Commission, which ruled that she was an 'employee' during her time on the show

Following their appearance on the renovation show, Fiona and Nicole faced abuse on social media and Nicole was unable to find work as a result.

'Since our episode and program aired I have not been able to obtain work and have been informed this was due to how I was portrayed as a bully,' she wrote.

'I feel devastated and worthless about the loss of my career and working life. After my episode aired, I wanted to kill myself and I started drinking more alcohol in an attempt to self-medicate my injury.'

Traumatised: 'After my episode aired, I wanted to kill myself and I started drinking more alcohol in an attempt to self-medicate my injury,' said Nicole (right)

The Commission's Arbitrator Cameron Burge ruled that Nicole was an 'employee' of Seven during her time on the show and that, during the course of her employment, she suffered a 'psychological / psychiatric injury'.

Seven's defence team argued that Nicole was not an employee of the network but the arbitrator ruled against them.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted Channel Seven for comment.
